description.narrative:
OUTCOME: Contribute to the establishment of a country platform that promotes the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals -SDGs- in Colombia, with emphasis in SDG 16, in order to advance towards the reduction of inequalities, the strengthening of territorial peace institutions and the diminution of political polarization.
The structure of outcomes within the contribution was redefined and the contribution's seven outcomes were reorganized into the following three strategic lines:
I. Institutional set-up for peace building and development
This strategic line will replace former Outcome 1 and intends to enhance coordination between the central and local governments (vertical coordination) and to strengthen institutional peacebuilding spaces at the local level (e.g. local peace secretariats). Special emphasis will be given to the support in the formulation of local Human Rights and Gender Public Policies. Former Outcomes 1 and 4 (result 4.2) will now report under this strategic line.
II. Dialogue and participation for Public Policy formulation and the achievement of Agenda 2030
This strategic is oriented towards the promotion of civil societys participation in decision-making processes for the formulation and implementation of public policies related with the SDG agenda and the implementation of the Peace Agreement. Former Outcomes 2 (results 2.4 and 2.5), 3 (result 3.4) and 5 (result 5.1) will now report under this strategic line.
III. Coexistence, reconciliation and reintegration
Under this strategic line, work will focus on generating dialogue capacities for the non-violent resolution of conflicts and the identification of local strategies that promote local peacebuilding. Former Outcomes 3 (results 3.5), 4 (result 4.3 and 4.8), 6 (result 6.2) and 7 will now report under this strategic line.
No additional resources were allocated for activities covered by former Outcome 7 (ELN peace process) since the peace talks are no longer taking place.

UNDP har ansökt om finansiering om 101 736 369 SEK för att genomföra "UNDP:s program för lokalt fredsbyggande 2016-2021". Det övergripande målet med programmet är att bidra till etableringen av en plattform som kan stödja implementeringen av FN:s globala mål - de globala målen för hållbar utveckling som är en del av Agenda 2030 för hållbar utveckling. Fokus är på mål 16 - fred, rättvisa och starka institutioner - för att kunna uppnå en minskning i ojämlikhet, och för att stärka lokala och nationella fredsinstitutioner och en minskning av den politiska polariseringen.

UNDP has applied to Sida for funding of 101 736 369 SEK, to carry out the “UNDP Program for local peace building 2016-2021”. The general objective of the Program is to contribute to the establishment of a country platform that promotes the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals -SDGs- in Colombia, with emphasis in SDG 16, in order to advance towards the reduction of inequalities, the strengthening of territorial peace institutions and the diminution of political polarization.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

tag.narrative: 16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

description.narrative:
During 2020, UNDP continued to foster the consolidation of 33 multi-stakeholder platforms for peace and development at local and national levels. These platforms facilitate dialogue between public authorities, civil society, and the private sector, promoting democratic decision-making around key issues as the protection of human rights, gender equality, environmental policies, and Peace Agreement implementation.
Unexpected results in this period emerged as a response to challenges imposed by the Covid-19 pandemic and extended lockdowns in Colombia, which led UNDP and other program partners to implement innovative approaches for reaching participants, fostering the protection of vulnerable communities and contributing with solutions for crises originated in the pandemic.
Examples of achieved results in 2020 are presented bellow along the programs three strategic lines:
Line 1. Institutional set-up for peacebuilding and development
The program provided technical assistance to local and regional elected authorities that took office in January for conducting a participative construction of their four-year development plans in eight departments and capital municipalities. In these processes, UNDP fostered the inclusion of SDGs and its indicators in local development plans. Support to local authorities in this area was key since the beginning of their mandate coincided with the Covid-19 pandemic, which implied challenges for civic participation due to mobility and assembly restrictions.
UNDP promoted the adoption of five environmental protection policies in different territories through assistance to local authorities. For example, five management plans for protected areas were updated and two new protected areas were declared in Antioquia with UNDPs support; technical assistance was provided for revising the development plan of the Peasant Reserve Zone of Catatumbo; and Metas government was accompanied to implement payments for environmental services and strategies to reduce deforestation.
In response to the intensification of violence against human rights defenders (HRD) and increased control of armed groups over communities, UNDP contributed to strengthen collective protection mechanisms: the Technical Secretariat of the National Guarantees Process was supported through methodologies, personnel and the campaign Estamos Contigo aimed at protecting HRD; technical assistance was provided to the National Protection Unit to improve the design and implementation of the Collective Protection Route; the municipal Ombudsman Offices (Personerías Municipales) were supported to implement protocols for acting during the Covid-19 pandemic; and the Indigenous Guard of the Regional Indigenous Council of Cauca (CRIC) was strengthened during the pandemic with biosecurity kits and articulation with local and national authorities.
Line 2. Dialogue and participation for public policy formulation and the achievement of Agenda 2030
UNDP continued to support the SDGs Multi-stakeholder Commission of the National Planning Department, through staff and methodologies to strengthen knowledge management and the construction of the Voluntary Local Report. The national SDG Corporate Tracker was formally launched on June 2020 and 400 private enterprises were trained to use the platform. Also, seven civil society organizations received funding to develop local initiatives to advance Agenda 2030 and SDGs.
In terms of participation, UNDPs field offices facilitated dialogue platforms and initiatives to promote gender equality and womens empowerment in Córdoba and Caquetá. Three citizens partnerships received technical assistance in Cauca and Nariño to participate in the construction of Local Development Plans. An Intercultural Dialogue platform was created for ensuring the meaningful inclusion of the Wayuu communities in the Human Rights Platform of La Guajira.
Through various activities at local level, 1.141 women and 177 womens organizations received training and technical assistance on leadership and decision-making, and 1.795 civic leaders participated in capacity-building strategies to foster social dialogue and conflict prevention.
Line 3. Coexistence, reconciliation and reintegration
Amidst the Covid-19 pandemic, programs partners Movilizatorio and Vive Bailando developed innovative strategies to reach young people in conflict-affected territories, whose vulnerabilities were generally heightened during the extended lockdowns. Through these initiatives, partners promoted youth engagement in networks to collaboratively build capacities and proposals to improve their well-being, which was critical to sustain social fabric in a period where meeting spaces for young people -school, universities, community centers- were largely closed.
The pandemic also challenged reintegration processes of former FARC members, since technical assistance of State institutions and international organizations could not reach the Former Territorial Aras for Reintegration and Training (FTART) due to biosecurity concerns and lack of internet connection. As a response, in partnership with IOM, the program facilitated satellite internet access and training for the use of virtual means in FTART, which allowed to continue providing technical support to 45 productive projects (2.640 beneficiaries) and 50 initiatives of economic empowerment for women in reintegration process and host communities (800 beneficiaries).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
